articles.headline: ISIS Declares Airstrike Killed a U.S. Hostage
articles.snippet: The Islamic State said Friday that Jordanian bombings in Syria intended to avenge the immolation of a captured pilot had killed an American hostage, Kayla Mueller, who was held by the group.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State said Friday that Jordanian bombings in Syria intended to avenge the immolation of a captured pilot had killed an American hostage, Kayla Mueller, who was held by the group.
articles.lead_paragraph: She had always been the unidentified, lone female American hostage of the Islamic State. For nearly 17 months, while her fellow American captives were beheaded one after another in serial executions posted on YouTube, Kayla Mueller’s name remained a closely guarded secret, whispered among reporters, government officials and hostage negotiators — all fearing that any public mention might imperil her life.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Home Loan Programs Let Buyers Put Less Down
articles.snippet: New options from Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and the F.H.A. require some research by would-be borrowers, who may decide it’s better to wait and save.
articles.abstract: New options from Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and the F.H.A. require some research by would-be borrowers, who may decide it’s better to wait and save.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the biggest hurdles to buying a home is accumulating the pile of cash for a down payment. By some estimates, it could take two decades to come up with a respectable 10 percent.

articles.headline: Rushing to Cater to America’s Rich
articles.snippet: As the U.S. economy turns around and upper-income spending falters in other countries, companies chase American millionaires.
articles.abstract: As the U.S. economy turns around and upper-income spending falters in other countries, companies chase American millionaires.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Houston, Chanel’s new 5,000 square-foot galleria is styled after Coco Chanel’s Baroque-inspired apartment, with bronze screens, an antique fireplace and a chandeliered shoe salon.

articles.headline: Brian Williams Faces ‘Fact-Checking’ Inquiry at NBC
articles.snippet: Controversy has continued to build about Mr. Williams’s apology for claiming that he was in a military helicopter that was forced down in Iraq.
articles.abstract: Controversy has continued to build about Mr. Williams’s apology for claiming that he was in a military helicopter that was forced down in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scrambling to contain a crisis engulfing one of its most prominent on-air personalities, NBC will begin an internal investigation into Brian Williams, the embattled evening news anchor who has admitted he misled the public with a harrowing tale of a forced helicopter landing in Iraq.

articles.headline: Knee Replacement Device Unapproved, but Used in Surgery
articles.snippet: The maker of the OtisKnee surgical guides started selling them before seeking clearance from the Food and Drug Administration, which later rejected the application.
articles.abstract: The maker of the OtisKnee surgical guides started selling them before seeking clearance from the Food and Drug Administration, which later rejected the application.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carla Muss-Jacobs didn’t give much thought to the tools her surgeon would use to replace her knee. Like most patients, she just wanted to feel better and trusted that any devices in the operating room would be safe.
articles.byline: By Marshall Allen and Olga Pierce

articles.headline: Data Breach at Anthem May Forecast a Trend
articles.snippet: Medical identify theft has become a booming business, according to security experts, who warn that other health care companies are likely to be targets.
articles.abstract: Medical identify theft has become a booming business, according to security experts, who warn that other health care companies are likely to be targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: After an online attack on Anthem, by far the largest breach in the industry, security experts warned on Friday that more attacks on health care organizations were likely because of the high value of the data on the black market.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Shivering, Hungry and Tearful in Rebel-Held Eastern Ukraine
articles.snippet: A new separatist offensive and the government’s push to isolate the region are intensifying problems as the fiercest winter weeks arrive on the Ukrainian steppe.
articles.abstract: A new separatist offensive and the government’s push to isolate the region are intensifying problems as the fiercest winter weeks arrive on the Ukrainian steppe.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Nikita, who has been living for several months with his mother and 1-year-old sister in a basement labyrinth of makeshift tents and rubber-bucket lavatories, explained why he cannot return to his toy-filled apartment.

articles.headline: Whodunit? In Obsessed Nation, Question Becomes Who Didn’t
articles.snippet: Argentina has been awash in theories about who killed Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor who accused President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of conspiring with Iran to cover up responsibility for the bombing of a Jewish community center.
articles.abstract: Argentina has been awash in theories about who killed Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor who accused President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of conspiring with Iran to cover up responsibility for the bombing of a Jewish community center.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The president did it. No, it was the Argentine spymaster plotting against her. Maybe it really was a suicide, the tragic fall of a man whose case was coming undone. Or was it Iran, the Israeli Mossad, the C.I.A.? And what about the lingering influence of the Nazis who fled here after World War II?

articles.headline: Economic Plan Is a Quandary for Hillary Clinton’s Campaign
articles.snippet: With advice from more than 200 policy experts, Mrs. Clinton is trying to figure out how to address the anger over income inequality without overly vilifying the wealthy.
articles.abstract: With advice from more than 200 policy experts, Mrs. Clinton is trying to figure out how to address the anger over income inequality without overly vilifying the wealthy.
articles.lead_paragraph: With advice from more than 200 policy experts, Hillary Rodham Clinton is trying to answer what has emerged as a central question of her early presidential campaign strategy: how to address the anger about income inequality without overly vilifying the wealthy.

articles.headline: For Saudis and Pakistan, a Bird of Contention
articles.snippet: A Pakistani court has canceled all foreign permits to hunt the houbara bustard, a favorite pastime of Arab royals, in response to complaints from conservationists.
articles.abstract: A Pakistani court has canceled all foreign permits to hunt the houbara bustard, a favorite pastime of Arab royals, in response to complaints from conservationists.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, royal Arab hunting expeditions have traveled to the far reaches of Pakistan in pursuit of the houbara bustard — a waddling, migratory bird whose meat, they believe, contains aphrodisiac powers.

articles.headline: Greek Austerity Spawns Fakery: Playing Nurse
articles.snippet: When patients go to a hospital in Greece, they often must hire their own nurses just to receive basic care, and many of those nurses are untrained and illegal.
articles.abstract: When patients go to a hospital in Greece, they often must hire their own nurses just to receive basic care, and many of those nurses are untrained and illegal.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Fotini Katsigianni wears a white nurse’s hat that protrudes prominently from the top of her head. She is head nurse at Evangelismos Hospital, one of the city’s most prominent.

articles.headline: Consumer Protection Agency Seeks Limits on Payday Lenders
articles.snippet: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is starting to draw up regulations that could sharply reduce the number of unaffordable loans from payday lenders.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is starting to draw up regulations that could sharply reduce the number of unaffordable loans from payday lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world of consumer finance, they are chameleons: payday lenders that alter their practices and shift their products ever so slightly to work around state laws aimed at stamping out short-term loans that can come with interest rates exceeding 300 percent.

articles.headline: Uncovering Security Flaws in Digital Education Products for Schoolchildren
articles.snippet: The law has long treated educational information as a category worthy of special protections, like credit or medical records, but the reality is often different.
articles.abstract: The law has long treated educational information as a category worthy of special protections, like credit or medical records, but the reality is often different.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tony Porterfield’s two sons came home from elementary school with an assignment to use a reading assessment site called Raz-Kids.com, he was curious, as a parent, to see how it worked. As a software engineer, he was also curious about the site’s data security practices.

articles.headline: Brian Williams, Retreading Memories From a Perch Too Public
articles.snippet: For some time now, there have been two versions of Brian Williams. One is an Emmy-winning, sober, talented anchor on the “NBC Nightly News” and the other is a funny, urbane celebrity.
articles.abstract: For some time now, there have been two versions of Brian Williams. One is an Emmy-winning, sober, talented anchor on the “NBC Nightly News” and the other is a funny, urbane celebrity.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some time now, there have been two versions of Brian Williams. One is an Emmy-winning, sober, talented anchor on the “NBC Nightly News” and the other is a funny, urbane celebrity who hosts “Saturday Night Live,” slow-jams the news with Jimmy Fallon and crushes it in every speech and public appearance he makes.

articles.headline: Comcast-Time Warner Cable Deal Still Up in the Air a Year Later
articles.snippet: The air of inevitability around Comcast’s proposed $45 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable has dissipated as the F.C.C. prepares to vote on a proposal to regulate the Internet like a utility.
articles.abstract: The air of inevitability around Comcast’s proposed $45 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable has dissipated as the F.C.C. prepares to vote on a proposal to regulate the Internet like a utility.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after it was announced, Comcast’s audacious acquisition of Time Warner Cable remains in limbo as Washington regulators scrutinize the deal. No surprise there. After all, the $45 billion merger would consolidate an already-concentrated industry, uniting the two largest cable operators in the United States.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Alabama Judge Defies Gay Marriage Law
articles.snippet: Chief Justice Roy S. Moore ordered local judges to ignore a federal court’s ruling that struck down Alabama’s ban on gay nuptials, reigniting a states’ rights debate similar to the one that arose during federally ordered integration.
articles.abstract: Chief Justice Roy S. Moore ordered local judges to ignore a federal court’s ruling that struck down Alabama’s ban on gay nuptials, reigniting a states’ rights debate similar to the one that arose during federally ordered integration.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — In a dramatic show of defiance toward the federal judiciary, Chief Justice Roy S. Moore of the Alabama Supreme Court on Sunday night ordered the state’s probate judges not to issue marriage licenses to gay couples on Monday, the day same-sex marriages were expected to begin here.

articles.headline: A Prickly Partnership for Uber and Google
articles.snippet: Google is a major investor in Uber, but as often happens in Silicon Valley, each company is working on products that could directly compete with the other’s.
articles.abstract: Google is a major investor in Uber, but as often happens in Silicon Valley, each company is working on products that could directly compete with the other’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Google’s venture capital arm poured more than $250 million into Uber in 2013, it looked like a match made in tech heaven.

articles.headline: With Paula Schneider as New Chief, American Apparel Shifts Focus
articles.snippet: Ms. Schneider is transforming a “wild, wild West” culture to one of discipline, while working to maintain a customer base that is “a little rebel.”
articles.abstract: Ms. Schneider is transforming a “wild, wild West” culture to one of discipline, while working to maintain a customer base that is “a little rebel.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When Paula Schneider took the helm at American Apparel’s sprawling factory and offices in Los Angeles last month, she found more than 3,000 cutters, sewers and designers working up a storm — but just one planner coordinating it all.

articles.headline: Gay Marriage in Alabama Begins, but Only in Parts
articles.snippet: The U.S. Supreme Court did not stay a ruling overturning Alabama’s ban, and many probate judges issued licenses in defiance of the state’s chief justice.
articles.abstract: The U.S. Supreme Court did not stay a ruling overturning Alabama’s ban, and many probate judges issued licenses in defiance of the state’s chief justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Despite a federal judge’s rulings legalizing same-sex marriage, most probate judges in Alabama on Monday refused to issue marriage licenses to gay and lesbian couples, escalating a legal showdown that echoed the battles over desegregation here in the 1960s.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Richard Pérez-Peña
